awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: DIAGNOSING THE TIMING AND DRIVERS OF NORTHEASTERN CARIBBEAN HOLOCENE DROUGHTS WITH SINKHOLE LAKE RECORDS
awd_abstract_narration:
This century, 80% of the world could face insufficient water necessary for food production, energy and national security, human health, and ecosystems. The United Nations estimates that Caribbean losses related to climate change by 2080 will be $11.2B, with $3.8B from drought. Rainfall in the Caribbean and American southeast is linked to similar ocean and atmospheric factors. However, geologic records of rainfall document extreme Caribbean megadroughts lasting tens to hundreds of years over the last several millennia. This project aims to identify and communicate the causes and drivers of these megadroughts through research and teaching American students at 3 institutions. It will help the United States, developing nations, and small island nations mitigate future water security risks. 

Climate model forecasts of rainfall changes in the American southeast and Caribbean for this century are currently equivocal, and available paleoclimate archives from the Caribbean document extreme megadroughts with a severity not observed in the instrumental era. These droughts were apparently not uniform across the Caribbean, and their causes remain poorly understood. Here, the investigators propose to develop a network of long-term rainfall records from key portions of the northern Caribbean using established geologic techniques and state-of-the-art climate modeling to diagnose the climatic drivers of Caribbean droughts.

This award is cofunded by the Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the project were to develop new records of rainfall and drought from sinkhole lakes in the northeastern Caribbean (northern Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), whose rainfall is highly sensitive to the North Atlantic Subtropical High (NASH), in order to: (a) identify the frequency and recurrence of megadroughts in the northeastern Caribbean; and (b) use climate models to diagnose the ocean and atmospheric drivers of northern Caribbean megadroughts to help inform hydroclimate model projections for this century. During the course of the project, >40 sinkhole lakes were hydrographically and stratigraphically investigated across the Bahamian archipelago for their suitability for paleoclimate research. While the sinkhole lakes are well known to the local populations, scientific literature on these sinkhole lakes was negligible to non-existent. With appropriate permits from the Government of The Bahamas prior to 2021, field work and subsurface coring activities produced many sediment cores that were shipped to laboratories in Texas, Massachusetts, and North Carolina for further scientific analysis. This project documented several new periods of drought (or aridity) versus pluvial conditions in the subtropical North Atlantic that were previously unknown to science. Our overarching conclusion is that western (or eastern) displacement of the North Atlantic Subtropical High has been a significant regulator of boreal summer rainfall during the last 6000 years. This is highly relevant to agricultural activities in the southern and southeastern United States whose productivity may be altered through changes in rainfall in the 21st century from changes in the geography of the western boundary of the North Atlantic Subtropical High. In addition, this project generated new information on the arrival of peopling of the northern Bahamas ~800 years ago, which was the last place colonized by humans in the Americas. The new knowledge learned during the course of this project was disseminated through 10 publications in the peer-reviewed literature, many in top journals in the field (e.g., Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Paleoceanography and Paleoclimatology), and 13 presentations at national scientific conferences (e.g., Geologic Society of America, American Geophysical Unition). Many of these research projects were first-authored by graduate students whose received direct training associated with this research project. The results have also been presented to local stakeholders in The Bahamas at scientific meetings, and at local elementary and high schools. This project directly contributed to the research and training of graduate students (3 PhD, 4 Masters). Texas A&M University at Galveston is primarily an undergraduate institution, and this project trained and involved over 40 undergraduate students in state-of-the-art techniques in climate science, paleolimnology, and sedimentology and stratigraphy. This includes 3 NSF-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates, and undergraduate students complete research-focused courses, and capstone undergraduate research projects.
